query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 La spada di qua sù non taglia in fretta 17 né tardo, ma’ ch’al parer di colui 18 che disïando o temendo l’aspetta.
query.result:
**English:**
16 The sword from up there does not cut quickly 17 nor slowly, but as it seems to him 18 who awaits it, desiring or fearing it.
**Old English:**
16 ðæs swurdes ecg ne mæg ðær on hrædran 17 ne on lætran, ac swa ðam gelimpð 18 ðe ðæs wæpnes or weneð or ondræt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Ma rivolgiti omai inverso altrui; 20 ch’assai illustri spiriti vedrai, 21 se com’ io dico l’aspetto redui».
query.result:
**English:**
19 But turn now to others; 20 for you will see many illustrious spirits, 21 if you direct your gaze as I tell you.
**Old English:**
19 Ac gewend ðe nu to oðrum; 20 forðæm ðu gesyhst fela mære gasta, 21 gif ðu ðone andwlætan wyrcst swa ic ðe lære.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Come a lei piacque, li occhi ritornai, 23 e vidi cento sperule che ’nsieme 24 più s’abbellivan con mutüi rai.
query.result:
**English:**
22 As it pleased her, I turned my eyes, 23 and I saw a hundred little spheres that together 24 adorned themselves more with their mutual rays.
**Old English:**
22 Swa swa heo wolde, ic mine eagan bewende, 23 and ic geseah hundteontig leohta ðe togædere 24 selran wæron mid hiwra gegyldenum leohtum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Poi dentro a lei udi’: «Se tu vedessi 32 com’ io la carità che tra noi arde, 33 li tuoi concetti sarebbero espressi.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Then within her I heard: "If you could see 32 how the charity that burns between us, 33 your thoughts would be expressed.
**Old English:**
31 Þa innan hire ic gehyrde: "Gif ðu gesawe 32 hu ðæt siblufu ðe us betweonan byrneð, 33 ðine geþohtas wæron awende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Ma perché tu, aspettando, non tarde 35 a l’alto fine, io ti farò risposta 36 pur al pensier, da che sì ti riguarde.
query.result:
**English:**
34 But why do you, waiting, not hasten 35 to the high end, I will answer you 36 just to the thought, since it so concerns you.
**Old English:**
34 Ac hwi ðu ðonne ðurh ðin wænunge 35 ðone hehstan ende ne ofearnedest, 36 ðonne wille ic ðe ðurh ðone geðoht andswarian, 37 siððan ðe he ðus sarig ðinceð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Questi altri fuochi tutti contemplanti 47 uomini fuoro, accesi di quel caldo 48 che fa nascere i fiori e ’ frutti santi.
query.result:
**English:**
46 All these other fires contemplating 47 were men, kindled with that warmth 48 which makes the holy flowers and fruits to grow.
**Old English:**
46 Ealle ðas oðre fyras byrninde 47 weras wæron, ðurh ðone wætan ontende 48 ðe ða halgan blostman and ða wæstmas weaxeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Qui è Maccario, qui è Romoaldo, 50 qui son li frati miei che dentro ai chiostri 51 fermar li piedi e tennero il cor saldo».
query.result:
**English:**
49 Here is Macarius, here is Romuald, 50 here are my brothers who within the cloisters 51 planted their feet and kept their hearts steadfast."
**Old English:**
49 Her is Machabeus, her is Romewold, 50 her syndon mine gebroðra ðe binnan clostrum 51 fæstnodon heora fet and heora heortan geheoldon."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 E io a lui: «L’affetto che dimostri 53 meco parlando, e la buona sembianza 54 ch’io veggio e noto in tutti li ardor vostri,
55 così m’ha dilatata mia fidanza, 56 come ’l sol fa la rosa quando aperta 57 tanto divien quant’ ell’ ha di possanza.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And I to him: "The affection that you show 53 in speaking with me, and the kind countenance 54 that I see and note in all your ardor,
55 has so increased my confidence, 56 as the sun does the rose when it opens 57 and becomes as large as it can.
**Old English:**
52 And ic to him: "Þæt gesæli ðe ðu sylst 53 mecum sprecende, and þæt gode andwlito 54 ðe ic geseo and gecnawe on eallum ðinum lustum,
55 swa hit hæfð geglencged minne treowe, 56 swa seo sunne ða rose ðonne heo open bið 57 swa micel wyrð swa heo mæge."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Però ti priego, e tu, padre, m’accerta 59 s’io posso prender tanta grazia, ch’io 60 ti veggia con imagine scoverta».
query.result:
**English:**
58 Therefore I beg you, and you, father, assure me 59 if I can receive so much grace that I 60 may see you with unveiled image.
**Old English:**
58 Forðæm ic bidde ðe, and ðu, fæder, me gesecge, 59 gif ic mæg ðone miclan miltse gefón, ðæt ic 60 ðe geseo mid ansýne unhided.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Ond’ elli: «Frate, il tuo alto disio 62 s’adempierà in su l’ultima spera, 63 ove s’adempion tutti li altri e ’l mio.
query.result:
**English:**
61 And he: "Brother, your lofty desire 62 will be fulfilled in the highest sphere, 63 where all the others and mine are fulfilled.
**Old English:**
61 And he: "Broðor, ðin heah gesceaft 62 bið gefylled on ðære utemestan speoran, 63 ðær bið gefylled ealle ða oðre and min.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Ivi è perfetta, matura e intera 65 ciascuna disïanza; in quella sola 66 è ogne parte là ove sempr’ era,
67 perché non è in loco e non s’impola; 68 e nostra scala infino ad essa varca, 69 onde così dal viso ti s’invola.
query.result:
**English:**
64 There is every desire perfect, mature, and whole; 65 in that alone is every part where it always was,
67 because it is not in space and does not unfold; 68 and our ladder reaches up to it, 69 from which it thus vanishes from your sight.
**Old English:**
64 Þær is ælc ðing fullfremed and fæger 65 and ungebrocen; on ðam anum is 66 ælc dæl þær he simle wæs,
67 forðæm hit nis stede ne stunde; 68 and ure stige stihð ðærto, 69 ðanon ðe hit ðus ðinum gesihðe bið.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Infin là sù la vide il patriarca 71 Iacobbe porger la superna parte, 72 quando li apparve d’angeli sì carca.
query.result:
**English:**
70 There below, the patriarch Jacob 71 saw the heavenly host offer him the supreme portion, 72 when it appeared to him laden with angels.
**Old English:**
70 Þær niðer ða geseah se ealda fæder 71 Iacob ða heofonlican werod him ða hyhstan dæl beodan, 72 ða him ða engeliscan ferðe ðus miclum wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Ma, per salirla, mo nessun diparte 74 da terra i piedi, e la regola mia 75 rimasa è per danno de le carte.
query.result:
**English:**
73 But to climb it, now no one departs 74 his feet from the ground, and my rule 75 has remained because of the harm of the charts.
**Old English:**
73 Ac for ðære stige, nu nænig mon 74 ne mæg his fotum of ðære eorðan astigan, 75 and min regol is forloren ðurh ðara ceastra hryre.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Le mura che solieno esser badia 77 fatte sono spelonche, e le cocolle 78 sacca son piene di farina ria.
query.result:
**English:**
76 The walls that used to be abbey-like 77 have become caves, and the cowls 78 are sacks full of bad flour.
**Old English:**
76 ða wallas ðe wæron ða gebaded 77 syndon nu speluncas geworden, and ða cucullas 78 syndon saccas fulle of yfele mele.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 La carne d’i mortali è tanto blanda, 86 che giù non basta buon cominciamento 87 dal nascer de la quercia al far la ghianda.
query.result:
**English:**
85 The flesh of mortals is so soft, 86 that down there a good beginning is not enough 87 from the birth of the oak to the making of the acorn.
**Old English:**
85 Þæs deadlican flæsc is swa hnesce, 86 ðæt ðær nyðan ne mæg nænig from frumða 87 æcerborenne ac to ðære æsctryðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Veramente Iordan vòlto retrorso 95 più fu, e ’l mar fuggir, quando Dio volse, 96 mirabile a veder che qui ’l soccorso».
query.result:
**English:**
94 Truly Jordan turned back 95 more, and the sea fled, when God willed, 96 a wondrous thing to see, that here the help.
**Old English:**
94 Soðlice Iordan gewende eft ongean 95 ma, and se sæ fleah, ða ða God wolde, 96 wundorlic to geseonne ðæt ðær ðæt fultum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Così mi disse, e indi si raccolse 98 al suo collegio, e ’l collegio si strinse; 99 poi, come turbo, in sù tutto s’avvolse.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Thus he said to me, and then he gathered himself 98 to his company, and the company gathered itself; 99 then, like a whirlwind, it all wrapped itself upwards.
**Old English:**
97 Swahe sæde, andsiððanhimgesomnade 98 tohishiwræden,andhiwrædhimgesomnade; 99 ða,swaðunor,uphalfgesomnade.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 S’io torni mai, lettore, a quel divoto 107 trïunfo per lo quale io piango spesso 108 le mie peccata e ’l petto mi percuoto,
109 tu non avresti in tanto tratto e messo 110 nel foco il dito, in quant’ io vidi ’l segno 111 che segue il Tauro e fui dentro da esso.
query.result:
**English:**
106 If ever I return, reader, to that devout 107 triumph for which I often weep 108 for my sins and beat my breast,
109 you would not have put your finger in the fire 110 as quickly as I saw the sign 111 that follows Taurus and was within it.
**Old English:**
106 Gif ic ðonne eft, ðu lædend, to ðam halgan 107 sigeþriume, ðurh ðone ic sar oft 108 mine synne bewepe and on breostum beate,
109 ðu næfre ðinne finger on fyr swa hræd 110 ne sende, swa ic ðæt tacen geseah 111 ðe ðam Steorre folgað and ðær binnan wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 O glorïose stelle, o lume pregno 113 di gran virtù, dal quale io riconosco 114 tutto, qual che si sia, il mio ingegno,
115 con voi nasceva e s’ascondeva vosco 116 quelli ch’è padre d’ogne mortal vita, 117 quand’ io senti’ di prima l’aere tosco;
118 e poi, quando mi fu grazia largita 119 d’entrar ne l’alta rota che vi gira, 120 la vostra regïon mi fu sortita.
query.result:
**English:**
112 O glorious stars, o light pregnant 113 with great virtue, from which I acknowledge 114 all, whatever it may be, my genius,
115 with you was born and with you was hidden 116 he who is the father of all mortal life, 117 when I first felt the Tuscan air;
118 and then, when I was granted the grace 119 to enter the high circle that revolves you, 120 your region was allotted to me.
**Old English:**
112 Eala, wuldorfulle steorran, eala leoht somod 113 mid micelre mihte, ðurh ða ic oncnawe 114 eall, swilce hit sie, min ingehygd,
115 mid eow wæs acenned and mid eow wæs gehýded 116 se ðe is fæder ælces deaddlices lifes, 117 ða ic ærest gehyrde ðone Tusciscan lyft;
118 and ða, ða me wæs ðæt gescyld geunnen 119 ðæt ic moste on ða hean hweowol ðe eow hwyrfeð, 120 ða wæs me eower rice geteohhod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 A voi divotamente ora sospira 122 l’anima mia, per acquistar virtute 123 al passo forte che a sé la tira.
query.result:
**English:**
121 To you devoutly now sighs 122 my soul, to acquire the virtue 123 for the difficult passage that draws it to itself.
**Old English:**
121 To ðe deoflice nu sigefæst sycað 122 min sawl, ðæt heo mæge ðone sped onfon 123 ðurh ðone fæstan fæðm ðe heo to tihð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Vidi la figlia di Latona incensa 140 sanza quell’ ombra che mi fu cagione 141 per che già la credetti rara e densa.
query.result:
**English:**
139 I saw the daughter of Latona burning 140 without that shadow that was the cause 141 for which I once believed her to be rare and dense.
**Old English:**
139 Ic geseah ðære Latenan dohtor byrnende 140 butan ðam sceade ðe me wæs gesceaft 141 ðurh ðæt ic ða gelyfde ðæt heo wære seldcwen and ðicce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 L’aspetto del tuo nato, Iperïone, 143 quivi sostenni, e vidi com’ si move 144 circa e vicino a lui Maia e Dïone.
query.result:
**English:**
142 The appearance of your son, Hyperion, 143 there I endured, and saw how Maia and Dione 144 moved around and near him.
**Old English:**
142 ðæs ðines suna ansyn, Yperiones, 143 ðær ic ðolode, and geseah hu ymbe hine 144 Maia and Dione meahtig wæron.
